source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: Iron additions varying up to 528 ppm by weight were studied in a Zr-1.4% Sn-0.1% O matrix. The results obtained are summarized in Table 2 and Fig. 1. The maximum solubility of iron in the alpha phase is 120 ppm at 820°C
composition_raw: Zr-1.4% Sn-0.1% O with iron additions up to 528 ppm

evidence_span: Size distribution of precipitates after a final annealing of 2 h at 750°C

extra_properties.precipitate_size_distribution: skew distribution with mode as characteristic variable

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk4
evidence_span: Equations used to predict particle growth kinetics by Kahlweit's theory

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk4
evidence_span: Linear growth in precipitate volume with time

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk4
evidence_span: increase in the iron + chromium content up to 1.5% has no significant effect on precipitate size

extra_properties.precipitate_size_effect: no significant effect from Fe+Cr content up to 1.5%

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk4
evidence_span: iron and chromium precipitate within about 1 min (600°C) and 5 min (500°C)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: The maximum solubilities of iron and chromium are 120 ppm for iron at 820°C, 200 ppm for chromium at 860°C, and 150 ppm for iron + chromium at 810°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: When the Fe/Cr ratio is less than 4 in matrices of this composition, the only precipitate phase is Zr(Fe,Cr)₂, in which the relative proportions of iron and chromium are close to their nominal values in the alloy

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: Comparison of the experimentally determined size distribution curves for the Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ particles with those calculated from Kahlweit's laws shows that precipitate growth involves second order kinetics

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: The precipitate volume grows as a linear function of time

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: Particle size increases with temperature, but is not affected by the concentration of iron + chromium in the alloy, up to levels of at least 1.5%

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: The iron and chromium precipitation followed by thermoelectric power measurements is very fast (a few minutes at 500 and 600°C)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: Influence of Fe + Cr content at different temperatures on modal diameter of particles

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: Evolution of the normalized thermoelectric power with the annealing time (ΔS t = 0 is the TEP of the as-quenched material in micro-volt/kelvin)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: Two differently heat treated Zr-4 materials have been analyzed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: It was found that the matrix in both materials was highly depleted with respect to iron and chromium

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: A difference in matrix iron content between the two materials was measured; the material with the longest intermediate annealings at higher temperatures was the least depleted of iron

extra_properties.annealing_effect: longer intermediate annealings at higher temperatures → less iron depletion

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk5
evidence_span: The material with high iron concentration in the matrix also showed the best uniform corrosion properties, as tested in autoclave

extra_properties.correlation: high matrix iron concentration → best uniform corrosion properties
